text: About that, there is no option.
Am I to understand that the Bynars have stolen the Enterprise?
An enormous amount of data is being received and stored in the main computer.

As I understand it, over time they've become so interconnected with the master computer on their planet that their language and thought patterns have become as near to binary as possible for organic beings.
At the moment, it's you who are setting the tone.  The sophistication of this programming is remarkable.
Bridge.  And you, Number One? You've earned a good rest. What are you going to do with it?
But why steal the ship? Why didn't they say something? Why didn't they just ask for help?
But, not to worry, Number One you're in good hands. Starbase 74 -- at warp two.
Cancel auto-destruct.
Come on, Number One. We've got to regain control of our ship!
Commander Riker and I will stay aboard, and be available should you need us.
Computer! Explain Red Alert.
Could it be that simple?  Try it.
Data, the Bynars have stored an enormous amount of information in the computer. We can't access it, and we must.
Destination?
Doesn't love always begin that way? With the illusion being more real than the woman?
Engage.
Evacuated!? Was the condition that critical?
Everything under control, Ensign Crusher?
Exit.
Explain.
Granted -- and welcome.
I don't dance.
I know, but what could it be?
I suppose it's an understandable progression. Computers make decisions based on inputs and we humans give off many subtle signs which communicate our emotions.
I think I'll be leaving.
I'll be in my Ready Room.
I'm sorry. Our mission can't be delayed. Can we postpone this work?
If we don't regain control, no one else will have it either. This is the only decision involving the operation of this ship which requires you and I to agree totally.
Impressive.
Incroyable! Vous etes Parisienne?
Is there anything we can do?
It appears to be successful. The system has started up -- a resident diagnostic program is running. Their system is incredible.
It takes several seconds to materialize. You wouldn't stand a chance.
It's another piece to this puzzle.
It's been some time since I had the Conn.

It's sufficient to get to the bridge... once there, either we'll get control of the ship and shut off the auto-destruct, or we won't. The important thing is that this ship does not fall into hostile hands.
It's the Bynars -- and you're part of this.
Let me get on the other position. The Bynars always work in pairs, perhaps that is also required.
Let's go. The only place we can stop the count is from the bridge.
Let's see if we can get some answers from Bynaus.
Locate Lieutenant Commander Data.
Maybe that too, was part of the Bynar's program. Some relationships just can't work.
Maybe.
No one's been hurt. They accomplished their objective. They have their world back in order, and we have our ship.
No, I'll wander down and see what's he doing to occupy himself. Keep me apprised.
No. We are very pleased with the operation of the Enterprise.
No. We'll beam in simultaneously in two different areas of the bridge.
Oh.  Have I been a topic of conversation?
Oui, au fonde nous sommes tous Parisienne. The spirit of that city can always restore my soul.
Perhaps they did.
Permission granted.
Position report.
Present condition.
Right. Coordinates for Main Bridge -- port forward for me and aft for you.
Set auto-destruct sequence.
She's very different from any images we've experienced on the Holodeck, isn't she? More -- you might say -- intuitive.
So what went wrong?
So you stole it.
Sorry, Number One -- I didn't mean to interrupt.
Starbase 74 -- this is the Enterprise.
Thank you, Number One. Well done, and well done all.
Thank you, no.
Thank you.
That explains, Riker... What about me?
That's our first stop, to verify the containment, and initiate auto-destruct.

The Holodeck has been able to give us woodlands and ski slopes and figures that fight and fictional characters with which we can interact -- but you are quite different. You adapt. You spoke French to me.
The ship has been commandeered by a force of unknown size and intent. We're here alone. We must assume the worst.
Their only chance was to transfer all the stored information and shut down until after it passed. Then, reactivate their system and transfer the information back to this main computer.
They appear dead.
They want us to find it. They would have kept it simple.
They went to a lot of trouble to clear computer space. See what they've stored.
They were desperate to steal this ship, bring it here to store all this information. Why?
They wouldn't intentionally hide it or make it difficult for us to find. It's got to be right in front of us.
They've locked it off.
This is Commander Riker.
This is your diversion, Number One. Not mine.
This way.
Turn them over to Quinteros.  There will be a hearing.
Two's company.
Under complete control.
We are all right, everything is fine. Now -- I want a complete check of all systems and divisions.
We'll get into that later. Right now I must speak with Lieutenant Commander Data.
We've got to find another way to get in.
Well done, Will. Now access the file and start the transfer.
Well, I'm going to put my feet up, turn on my personal relaxation light and lose myself in the pages of some old novels.
What about all the people in that world who are totally dependant on their computer? Are they still functioning?
What do they want with the Enterprise? What's their purpose?
What?
Where's Commander Riker?
Why did you steal my ship?
Why didn't you just ask for our help?
Why wasn't I notified?
You have forty-eight hours, because at forty-eight plus six we have an appointment at Pelleus Five which we must keep.
You picked a wonderful locale. Something I might have chosen myself.
Your reputation precedes you. I am pleased you will be improving our system.
bridge, this is the captain. Situation report.
A singer?
And an impostor running my ship.
And what if there is, Mister Tholl? Shall we continue accusing one another until hostility leads to violence? Shall we allow our suspicions to destroy us?
And you, sir?
As you wish, Mister Tholl.  We must open this panel.
Attempting to show our captors that we possess intelligence.
Because kidnapping is immoral. The lives of other races must be respected.

Because there's something more you can learn from us. With an alert crew, even our "primitive vocal communications" are unnecessary. Commander Riker understood I wished to hold you here...  ... he had Mister Data scan you and pass the information to our security officer...  ... who devised a forcefield that would entrap you.
Both of you -- this is getting us nowhere.
Captivity is an injury, regardless of how it's justified.
Cor Caroli Five...
Doctor...
Engage.
Esoqq -- I've been trying to determine if we have a common enemy... someone who'd have reason to confine us here.
Esoqq -- how long can you go without food?
Food.
Food?
Four sleeping areas... that implies we'll be joined by another captive...
Good enough to be useful to our abductors?
Haro -- stand back.
Has it a meaning?
Hold your positions. Take no action.
I agree we're taking a risk. But I see no alternative.
I can't.
I don't think it will be. Esoqq -- your knife, please.

I found it unlikely that a first-year cadet would know of the Enterprise's visit to Mintaka Three... so I tested you. Starfleet has classified the Cor Caroli Five plague "secret." No cadet would have knowledge of the incident.
I think this charade has gone far enough, don't you?
I'll take the chance. It's imperative that we communicate with our abductors... find out what they want.
I'm not suggesting anything. I'm merely trying to come up with an explanation for your abduction.
I've decided to perform an experiment of my own. I want to see how you react to being imprisoned.
It would seem a new arrival is imminent...
It would seem so.
It's all right. I'm not going to hurt you.
It's imperative.

It's the only explanation. Look at the four of us... we do have something in common: we all react differently to authority.  You, the anarchist, reject authority in any form...  ... you, the collaborator, defer to whoever's in control...  ... I, a Starfleet Captain, am trained to command...  ... and you, a cadet, have sworn to obey a superior officer's authority.  Our captors put us here and devised obstacles for us to overcome. We were given food Esoqq couldn't eat -- to make him a threat. We were given a door that wouldn't open -- until all four of us cooperated. And each time we succeeded, we were dealt a reversal -- to set us against each other again.  While you observed our reactions.
Jean-Luc Picard of the Enterprise.
Let's see if we can deactivate that stun mechanism...
Make it so.
Mister Crusher. Set course for our rendezvous with the Hood... Warp eight.
Mister Tholl...
No longer?
None? In the last three hundred years of Mizarian history, your planet has been conquered six times!
Nonetheless, Mister Tholl --
Not perfect in what way?
Number One?
Obviously. But why? What made our captors choose us? What makes us special?
Of course they will. They'll do everything they can. In the meantime, we keep our heads...  ... and enjoy the hospitality.
Or against you personally?
Picard to Enterprise.
Punished -- how?
Quite a while, Mister Tholl. And I'm perfectly willing to entertain the hypothesis that our captors are Romulans.  But what would Romulans want with you?
Status, Number One?
Stop! We mean you no harm...
That would appear to be the power lead to the stun device.
That, I can't answer.  The Bolians are maintaining an uneasy truce with the Moropa, are they not?
Then my doppelganger caused no serious damage.  Was the replica convincing?
Then you have no idea who might have done this.
They may not realize we are communicating through language.
Tholl -- I asked her to open the door.
Tholl -- our captors have transporters and stun beams. I hardly think they'd try to keep us at bay with a knife.
To get their attention.
Unfortunately, I can't, Mister...
We are prisoners, like yourself! We are not the enemy!
We can no longer afford to be patient. If we don't act soon, Esoqq will starve...
We don't know. We were brought here the same way you were. Our captors refuse to show themselves.
Well, Mister Tholl, all I know is that I've been brought here against my will.  Wherever "here" is...
What I want is for all of us to escape.
What can you tell me about our captors?
What's your best area of study?
Why not?
Yes, you do. This isn't a holding cell; it's a laboratory maze -- and we're the white rats. A carefully concocted test... an experiment to see how we'd react under pressure.
Yes. I visited there twelve years ago.
You had no right to put us through this just to satisfy your curiosity.
You have many enemies?
You may as well drop the pretense. I refuse to play along any further -- I'm quitting the game. As far as I'm concerned, this experiment is over.
You must trust us. We wish only to return to our worlds. Were you abducted from Chalna?
You're a Bolian. There are very few Bolians in Starfleet.
-- away team?
Agreed. And keep me advised.
And the --
Angel One's position in this quadrant may become strategically vital. The hope at Starfleet is that some day this planet could become a part of the Federation.
Don't be ridiculous, Doctor. I've got an away team down there, in less-than-friendly territory, not to mention an appointment with the several Romulan battlecruisers...
Don't let this "just happen" again, Mister Crusher.
Energize!
Enter.
Enter.
Except, let us hope, for the Odin escape pods.  Since this is a female-dominated society, it might be more prudent if you made the initial contact, Counselor.
How contagious is it?
I guess I'm better at giving orders than taking them.
I want all departments prepared for a warp six trip to the Neutral Zone as soon as the away team completes its mission.
Insurance. Romulan battlecruisers have been detected near one of our border posts. They've requested assistance as soon as we are available.
Is it contained?
Is that an order?
Keep me--  --advised. You'll have the bridge until Commander Riker returns.
Lieutenant La Forge -- you have command until further notice. Please make the proper entries in the ship's log.
Lieutenant Worf and I... detected a similar scent when we bumped into... your son at the Holodeck.
Make it so, Mister La Forge. What kind of place is this, Data?
No.
On the Enterprise, Mister Crusher, nothing "just happens."  What is that smell?
On the mend, thank you. Tell me about Angel One.
Picard here.
Please stay with it, Doctor. Starfleet has important business for us as soon as the away team returns. I don't relish having my crew infected.
Report, Mister Crusher.
Same... you gave me last birthday.

Starfleet was quite adamant that we maintain excellent diplomatic relations with this planet. Any other pertinent information before we reply, Mister Data? Their form of government would be a logical starting place.
Status report, please.
That's their prerogative, Lieutenant.  Prepare the away team, Number One.
This is all quite unnecessary, Doctor.  I'm merely fatigued.
You are excused, Doctor.
As of now, we don't have sufficient evidence one way or the other... I want you to examine her shuttle... perhaps there's something there which will shed some light on her story.
Computer -- locate Commander Morag and Lieutenant Uhnari.
Could a high level phaser blast have caused this kind of DNA disruption?
Did you kill Lieutenant Rocha?
Do you have any idea what killed her?
Doctor... what exactly is this?
Get Rocha's personnel file from Starfleet Command. And ask Starbase Two-Twelve to help search for that shuttle.
Governor Torak... we are merely exploring all the possibilities. Lieutenant Uhnari's logs said Commander Morag was harassing the station --
Governor, we would like Commander Morag to remain aboard the Enterprise until our investigation is complete.
Governor. Welcome aboard...
If he was only doing his job, then I'm sure you won't mind if we speak with him.
If what you're saying is true... Rocha attacked Uhnari because he needed a new body...
Keep me apprised.
Lieutenant... why didn't you contact Starfleet and report what happened aboard the Station?
Life signs?
Perhaps Morag was the one interested in obtaining the encrypted messages.
The Klingon ship Qu'Vat has arrived with Governor Torak. Please report to the Observation Lounge.
There hasn't been a Klingon raid against the Federation in over seven years.  I don't want to risk a diplomatic incident until we have more evidence.
This should be an interesting meeting.
Torak claims to be bringing evidence that the Klingons had no involvement in the murder of Lieutenant Uhnari.
Very well. In the meantime, I'll talk to the Klingon Governor about Commander Morag.
What have you found out about Uhnari?
Why?
You said it was formed from the organic matter found in the deckplate?
You think she lied?
A life-form... ?
And it's been determined that they date back to the late nineteenth century... ?
And let me miss all this? I haven't seen such a complex operation since the Academy lab final in exochemistry.
Any sign of life?
Can you build one?
Can you determine how long it has been in the cavern?
Cellular fossil... ?
Cheat fate... ? Perhaps we can't, Mister Data. But, to be honest, I don't think I could forgive myself... if we didn't at least give it a try.
Could it be Lore?
Guinan, if you have something to tell me, I'm listening.
How soon will you be ready?
I don't want anyone else going in alone.
I have reason to believe my presence on this mission is imperative.
I hope that's true, Data. Nevertheless, this investigation began with your death... I am simply trying to see that it doesn't end the same way.
I see no reason why we shouldn't take reasonable precautions...
I'm curious, Doctor. There are far greater experts on Earth who could investigate your mystery. Why bring the Enterprise all the way home?
Is it... yours, Data?
Make it so.
Mister Data cannot be our priority...
Mister Data, I'll need you on the bridge to monitor the sensor readings during this investigation...
Number One, lay in a course...
Of course.
Perhaps in the course of our investigation we will. I hope so.
Proceed, Mister La Forge.
Proceed.
Take an away team.
Take us into a standard orbit above those coordinates...
That's general policy...
The security of the Enterprise is of paramount importance, Lieutenant.
Then, I shall be irrational.
This is rather unusual... for you to be curious about an away mission...
Triolic waves?
Type R?

We have to operate on the assumption that there is a threat... if not to us then to 19th-century Earth. Our first order of business is to determine what that threat may be.  In order to do that, Mister La Forge, we must find a way to communicate with these life-forms...
What did you want to see me about?
What do you mean?
What makes you think extraterrestrials are related to this discovery...
Why can we see them when they can't see us?
Why?
Would these triolic waves be dangerous to humanoids?
Yes, yes I am aware of that...
Yes.
Yes.  Mister Worf, you will report to the bridge.
Agreed. Let's get out of here.
Ah -- just in time! We need someone to read a part...
Ah. The... rent.
Are you injured?
Believe me, in the future the tables will be turned.
Can you communicate?
Coming, Mrs. Carmichael...
Don't try to sit up too quickly... you've lost a lot of blood.
Follow him!
Guinan...
Hello, Officer. This the Infirmary?
History fulfilling itself...
I can't very well let anything happen to you... you're far too important to me.
I hope they're safely back on the Enterprise by now.
I think we've found our Titania...  ... don't you agree?
I'll see you... in a few minutes.
I'm going to get help. We have to get you out of here...
If they're moving among humans, they must have taken human form. The question is, how do we know who we're looking for... ?
If we can get back there... and destroy that site... can we put an end to their time traveling... ?
It goes beyond friendship.
It's -- "A Midsummer Night's Dream."
Mrs. Carmichael, my troupe is even now in rehearsals for a new production.
No. Because for me, it won't have happened yet.
No. You need help.
Not yet. But you will.
Now, Mrs. Carmichael...  Right there...
Perhaps we could find a substitute...
Replacing the wick screws. City ordinance... makes it safer in case of an earthquake.
Thank you.  I wish time had allowed me to know you better...
That's it for this ward. Have to be moving on.
Very well.
We cannot allow that.  We know how you move back and forth through time... my crew has returned to the twenty-fourth century to destroy your transport site on Devidia Two --
We have a bill at Mrs. Carmichael's boarding house --
We have no choice but to try.
We've performed in London... Paris... Milan... all to sold out houses. I assure you, we'll be able to pay the rent... with a bonus.
Well, I don't need to hear any more. That was -- truly unique.
Yes... ?
You hunt us... you kill us. We cannot allow that.
You see? We'll begin rehearsals tomorrow.
You were hurt. I had to make sure you were all right.
You'll have to get help. Guinan needs medical attention...
All right. Stay with me, Doctor. Keep talking...
Beverly!
Can you remove it?
Can you stop it?
Careful, Number One.
Come on, stay with me, Doctor.
Data!
Data, assign it a neutral target.
Data, have you been able to assess Commander Riker's condition?
Data... Lieutenant Yar.
Doctor -- you have to stay awake -- you have to help me! Tell me what to do.
Doctor Crusher has been seriously injured. Our communicators are out and I haven't been able to contact the Enterprise.
Doctor!
Enterprise.
Give me some options, Data... Quickly.
He's alive. What he ran into is an intelligence gathering device used during the Ersalrope Wars.
Help me -- you've got to help me!
Hold on. It won't be long.
Hold on. We'll get you out of here.  Enterprise, this is the Captain. Two to beam up.
How bad is it?
I am Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the USS Enterprise. To whom am I speaking?
I can't find your medical kit.
I don't know.
I don't know. But it's all right because once they realize our communicators are out, the sensors will locate us and Geordi will beam us up.
I understand.
I'd call that arrogant.
I've stopped the bleeding --
If an automated message system is still functioning -- other systems on the planet may also be operational.
If that's what it takes to shut it off. Yes... I've seen enough -- you've made a sale.
Is it possible to re-adjust the targeting sequence?
Is that possible?
It must be left over from the time of the Romulan wars, when the business of selling arms was booming.
It projects an image of someone the subject will trust -- gets as much information as possible.
It's very bitter --
Itself, then. Have it track itself or the power source that manufactures it.
Keep up your end. Stay awake. That's an order, Doctor.
Lieutenant La Forge.
Lieutenant Solis, situation report.
Lieutenant Solis?
Mister Data?
No, but I'll find something.
None that I know of. Number One, those devices are part of a system which is located down here. Another is about to be released.
None?
Noted.
Now... end the demonstration.
Number One, get your team back here.
Number One, weren't you offered the Drake?
Number One?
Oh, no you don't -- no time to sleep.
Oh.
Possibly.
Prepare your away team, Number One.
Put it on the Main Viewer.
Screen off.
Shut it off.
Stand by. I'm coming down.
Standard orbit, Mister La Forge.
Stay alert, Doctor! That's an order, damn it!
Tell me about him.
The patient has lost a great deal of blood from multiple lacerations. What's your diagnosis, Doctor?
Theorize. What's the purpose of the encasement?
These?
This is going to hurt a bit, Doctor.
Transporter Room Three - have you locked on to the away team?
We have little choice. Whatever has him is interrupting the transporter beam. Remove it.
We have to find a way to stop this system.
We've seen enough.
What do I do?
What do we do next, Doctor?
What else can I do?
What is it?
What was that noise?
What's going on Number One?
Whatever happens below, your prime responsibility is to the ship.
Which would suggest what?
Yes -- we're here.
Yes, I heard, Number One. We'll try to track it down from here.
Yes.  Doctor Crusher, this is the Captain. Meet me in Transporter Room Three.  Mister La Forge, you have command of the bridge.
You know Captain Rice?
You poor fools. The first time you tested it, or demonstrated it... something went wrong and your creation destroyed you.
Your sensors indicated no intelligent life?
... and another full day for their answer to return. I'd like the truth on this by then.

A "save our skins" maneuver. The Stargazer was on fire, finished. We had to abandon ship, and limp through space in shuttlecraft for weeks before being picked up.  I haven't thought about it in years...
A little sleep, thanks to the doctor, works wonders. Any report on the logs?
A lot of effort for something as simple as a headache.
AGHHH-H-H!!
Aghhh! My head!
Ah... my weapons officer on the Stargazer.  I was getting caught up in this.
Ah... no, of course. It was... the memory I was calling up.  Sorry.
And our attacker fired on the wrong one.
And so why do I have a headache, Doctor?
Are you accustomed to always getting your way, Doctor?

Are you sure it wasn't one of my thoughts? At that moment, I was remembering being at the helm of the Stargazer, a maneuver being made. We were hit...  Something's burning... I smell smoke!  Don't you smell it?
Carry on.  Answer the first officer's question.
Certainly you know what a "headache" is, Doctor.
Come!
Concur.  Stand by!  Let's bring them on visually.
Consider ourselves reminded.  Open hailing frequencies.
DAMNNNN!
Damage report!
Damn!  I'll call the doctor again.
Damn, I said...  ... put fusion generators on surge control.  You're moving too slowly. Arm the torpedoes, man!
Data? What do you read?
Didn't I? I don't know anymore... I just don't know.
Do not attack again! We are on a peaceful...
Do we know each other?
Doctor, all I've got is...
Don't you know it is, Number One?
Enlarge please, La Forge.
Enterprise to Ferengi vessel. We are standing by to receive you.
Enterprise, lock on. Beam me home, Riker.
FIRE!!
Ferengi vessel! This is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the Enterprise. We are transmitting visually.
Fine, Doctor.  Lieutenant Yar, run a structural analysis on the Stargazer for impulse tow.  Data, download all computers to the Enterprise and file...  I'm going to my old cabin.
Fire!
For what purpose? What is this all...
Give your identity! You force us to defend ourselves!  Phasers full up! Arm torpedoes! Why aren't shields at full power... ?
Have they given any hint what they've been waiting for?
Hello, old friend...
I appreciate your offer, DaiMon Bok, and ask you to be our guests.
I can't either. But they could be baiting some kind of trap...
I got the damn headache before I even knew my old ship still existed...  But maybe you're partly right...
I have no idea what you're talking about...
I improvised. With the other ship coming in for the kill...  ... I ordered a sensor bearing, and when it went into its return arc...
I mean you too, Doctor. I have business with Riker.
I thought I was captain of this starship, Doctor.
I want to go over to her.
I will that, Number One.  Energize!
I'm afraid you have the advantage. Is this... Bok?
I'm all right now; I'm fine.  What is this all about?
I'm sorry, I'm afraid I do not. Data?
Is that you, Vigo?
It hasn't been! But it is getting worse, Doctor...
It must've been lying in a deep moon crater nearby. The first attack damaged our shields, and in the confusion it hit us a second time.
It... he is not for sale. Commander Data is...is...
It... it is the Stargazer. My old ship, but how... where did you find it?
Main Viewer.
Me? Why me? I've never heard of him.
More like dying, Doctor. What's wrong with me?!
My sincere regrets, Bok, but that ship did not identify itself. It simply attacked; we defended ourselves...
No name, no reason...  Can you identify them, Vigo? Our shields are failing; if they come in again... ?
No!
No. Her inertia will carry the Stargazer along on this heading with us. Or did you sleep through the Academy lecture on conserving tractor beam power?
No... no, I'm fine...
Not as much as this damn headache, Counselor. Take over, Number One.
Nothing, just... a mild headache.  The correct procedure, Ensign, would have been to signal your finding to the bridge immediately.
OHHHH!
OHHHHH... ! OHHHHH... !
On my way, Number One.  Sorry, Doctor. Duty calls.
Once again...
One hour, Bok. End transmission.
One of our starships under your control?
Perhaps... it hit with more impact.
Phaser...  Yes, a sphere... Bok used it...
Phaser... destroy the sphere.
Question... where shall we receive you?
Ready phasers!
Ready phasers, and lock!  Stand by for warp nine, heading seven, seven mark twenty...  And ENGAGE!
Release the Stargazer from the tractor beam, Number One.
Sensor bearing on hostile ship!
Stand by for warp...  Who are you?!
Steady. NOW reverse and stop!  Phasers FIRE! Torpedoes AWAY!
Strange, Number One. Like visiting the house you grew up in, but no one's home, except the phantoms of the past...
Thank you for your confirmation of that.  But now, except for Commander Riker, I want you all back at your stations...  Is that clear?
Thank you, Will.  I never made that log entry, of course. But it still creates a duty for you to perform.
The Stargazer was an exploration vessel. The fight at Maxia was not my first action, but it was the first time I ever killed anyone.

The last three nights, I... hear voices. I'm standing on the bridge, fire all around me... the klaxons, smoke, and I give the order...  And now the Stargazer is really here!  And that log... Am I going crazy? How do I know if I was in my right mind at Maxia? How do I know if I'm in my right mind now?
The pain's gone.
The reason for it seems fairly obvious. What are these Ferengi up to? "Stand by, Enterprise." Stand by for what?
The ship... ? The... the Ferengi ship that attacked me...  ... or is it about to attack me?
The tractor beam.
Then, in one hour we'll know why.
They agreed a bit too easily.
This is my first officer, Commander Riker...  And Counselor Troi. Second Officer Data; Lieutenant La Forge; security officers, Lieutenant Yar and Lieutenant Worf; Ensign Crusher.
Time? Oh, for the Ferengi to beam over.  Do you see any problems connected with this old starship coming in?
Vigo! Get a fire control party up here!
We welcome you in peace to the Enterprise, DaiMon Bok.
We were traveling at warp two through the Maxia Zeta star system when an unidentified starship suddenly appeared and fired on us! From close range.
Weapons report!
Well, it was strong, whatever it was.  Ready, Number One.
What I need now is a friend...
What any good helmsman could have done. I dropped into high warp...  ... then stopped right off the target vessel's bow...  ... and fired everything I had.
What are you doing?
What do you find, Data?
What does this mean?
What is happening?
What problem is that, DaiMon Bok?
What was... that?
What's that?
Who are they? Identify them!
Who the hell is it?!
Who?
Why do doctors always state the obvious like it's a revelation?
Why shouldn't they? Better safe than sorry with the Ferengi now making friendship overtures.
Yes, Commander
Yes, Doctor. I've been feeling... odd, lately. Fatigued. And now I've got a headache.
Yes, but... my things here...
Yes... sleep... I need sl...

You are using your position as a Starfleet officer to affect political change on your planet... there could not be a worse compromise of our fundamental principles...
You have manipulated the circumstances, ladies, with the skill of a Romulan.  My decision will be announced at high sun tomorrow. Excellent tea. Good day.
Your discommendation is a facade intended to protect men less honorable than you. It is a lie... and lies must be challenged.
Your invitation was... unexpected.
Your tactical knowledge and experience should serve them well.
Acknowledged.
Agreed. But if the Duras are being aided by the Romulans, then it becomes very much our concern.
All right. Why did I invite you?

And some would say they must be getting help.  The Romulans have always been willing to take enormous risks in order to gain any advantage over the Federation.  Can we seriously believe that now, with the future of the entire Klingon Empire hanging in the balance, they are content to simply stand by and watch?
And yet you claim that it is possible -- that Tasha Yar was your mother.
As it now stands, I don't see how this has any impact on our present strategy. We'll continue the blockade and leave the next move to them.
Begin long-range scans of the Romulan border.
Besides, Tasha would have been a child when this woman was born.
But why? What possible advantage do the Romulans think they would gain?
Come.
Commander... I believe the starship Sutherland will need a captain. I can think of no one more suited to the task than you.
Deploy the fleet, Will. It's time to spread our net.
Doubts? I'm full of them. Nothing in my experience can assure me that what you say is true... but I do know one thing: it will not affect my judgment in our next encounter.
Engage.
Exactly.  But when they try to send their ships through, the Enterprise and the Tian Nan Men will swing around, close the gap and catch them in the act.
Good luck, Will.
Good.  Course one one eight mark three five seven, full impulse power  Signal the fleet to get underway. We'll enter warp once we're clear of the system.
Granted.
Guinan... that was twenty-three years ago... Tasha was still a child...
Hail the Sutherland.
How could you know these things?
I think the Romulans have created what they hope will be a distraction... something to keep us off balance.
I think... it's time I met Commander Sela.
I want the fleet to be underway by oh nine hundred tomorrow. Thank you, gentlemen.

I want to add the Tian Nan Men, the Hermes, and the Sutherland to join us whether the yard superintendent thinks they're ready or not. Mister Data, select a group of experienced officers from the Enterprise to augment the crews of those ships.
I want to meet her.
I'm afraid you misinterpret our presence here. I want to reassure you that we have no hostile intentions.
If you have nothing more than a vague intuition...
If you launch a massive attack now, the Duras forces will need supplies... Lursa and B'Etor will call for help... the Romulans will try to run the blockade... and we'll be ready for them.
In thirteen hours we will be forced to either withdraw from the border or fight the Romulan fleet. Neither of those alternatives is acceptable. We must expose their involvement before the deadline.
It is most certainly our intent to prevent any external power from interfering in Klingon affairs.

It's been suggested that Tasha was aboard the Enterprise-C when it was destroyed twenty-four years ago. She was one of the survivors. You are obviously the product of a union between her and a Romulan.
Mister Data...
Mister La Forge, how long do you think it will take the Romulans to detect the tachyon field once it's activated?
Mister La Forge, will we be able to implement your tachyon detection grid with twenty ships?

My chief engineer has developed a system that should help us nullify that advantage. Each ship will send out an active tachyon beam to the other ships in the blockade fleet. In theory, any cloaked vessel that tries to pass between our ships should cross one of those beams and be detected.
Nicely done.

No, they can't.  However... the excuse "I was only following orders" is the epitaph of too many tragedies in our history. Starfleet does not want officers who will blindly follow orders without analyzing the situation.  Your actions were appropriate for the circumstance, and I have noted that in your record.
Not at all. Is something wrong?
Not yet.
On screen.
Open a channel to the Excalibur.
Open a channel to the Sutherland.
Signal the fleet to maintain yellow alert until further notice.
Signal the fleet to stand by.
So do I, Number One.
Tasha died... a year before you came to the Enterprise. You never met her.
Tasha?
That's where they're going through.  Send a signal to the fleet... all ships to fall back and rendezvous at Gamma Eridon. We'll try to reestablish the net before they get there.
The Enterprise C? It was lost... at the battle of Narendra Three... while defending a Klingon outpost from the Romulans.

The Romulans have been trying to destroy the Federation/Klingon Alliance for over twenty years, and at the same time, the Duras have been secretly conspiring with the Romulans.  Doesn't it strike you as odd that the Duras are able to field such an overpowering force against Gowron? That they outmatch him at almost every turn?
Then why not send your ships across?
Then you believe her, Counselor?
There have been three major engagements in the last two weeks... all of them won by ships loyal to the Duras family.
There were stories... that there might have been prisoners, taken back to Romulus. But those were just rumors.
They've probably been sitting there watching us for some time now.
Those anomalies could be cloaked ships.
Very well. Energize the network.

We must stop the flow of supplies and equipment from the Romulans to the Duras family.  I propose we take a fleet of ships to the Romulan/Klingon border. We'll take no offensive action, but we'll be in a position to expose any Romulan shipments that try to cross the border.
We're reading a disruption of the tachyon net in your area.
Well... I felt that you were needed here.  Why do you ask?

When Gowron begins his attack, we'll make our move.  The Excalibur will fall back with "engine problems." You will take the Hornet and the Akagi to this position... which will open a small gap in our detection net.
Will, I want you to command the Excalibur. Her crew was reassigned when she put in for repairs. Geordi, you'll serve as his first officer.
Yes, Data?
Yes.
Your mother. Is she still alive?
Again, welcome aboard, Captain.
Aldeberan whiskey.  Who do you think gave it to Guinan?
Bon voyage, Mister Scott.
Bridge to Transporter Room Three. Stand by to beam two from the Jenolen as soon as we're in range.
Bridge to Transporter Room. Energize.  Fire torpedoes.
Bring us out of warp, Ensign. All stop.
But... ?
Call it... an extended loan. Since you lost your ship while saving ours, it seemed only fair.
Can you localize the source of the gravity field?
Come.
Commander. I'd like you to accompany Mister Scott.
Constitution class...
Ensign Rager, take us into synchronous orbit above that position.
Full sensor sweep, Mister Data. Where are we?
Go ahead Number One.
Good. I look forward to it.  Commander, we need to begin a full spectrographic analysis of the Dyson Sphere.
Good. Stand-by.  Can we use the phasers to open a hole in the sphere?
How are you feeling?
How long will it take us to reach them?
I hope I'm not interrupting, but I was just coming off duty and wanted to see how you were doing.
I must say I was more than a little surprised when Commander Riker informed me you were aboard the Jenolan. Our records didn't list you as one of their crew.
I see. Well, I would very much enjoy the opportunity to discuss your career at some point. History is one of my hobbies and I'm sure you have some fascinating insights into the events of your time.
I'm Captain Jean-Luc Picard. Welcome aboard the Enterprise, Captain Scott.
Is there any indication that the sphere is inhabited?

It's a very old theory, Number One. I'm not surprised you haven't heard of it. A twentieth century physicist, Freeman Dyson, postulated that an enormous hollow sphere could be constructed around a star. This would have the advantage of harnessing all the radiant energy of the star. A population living on the interior surface would therefore have a virtually inexhaustible source of power.
Maneuvering thrusters?
Mister Data, begin a scan of the interior surface for life forms. I want to know who brought us in here and why.
Mister Data, could this be a... Dyson Sphere?
Mister Data, we need to find a way out of here. Begin scanning for another hatch or portal that might still be open.
Mister La Forge, I understand that the Jenolen conducted an extensive survey of the Dyson sphere before it crashed. Have we been able to access those records?
Mister Worf, open a channel to that array.
No. But it may be enough to turn us into orbit and hold our distance from the photosphere.
Perhaps Captain Scott could be of use in accessing that material.
Port thrusters ahead full, starboard back full.
Report.
Send out a series of class four probes to survey the far side of the sphere. Perhaps we'll have more luck with them.
Seventy-five years is a long time. If you'd like to study some of the technical --
Shields?
Thank you.
That would explain why they abandoned it.  But if there's no one still living here, how were we brought inside?

The first ship I ever served aboard as Captain was called the Stargazer... it was an overworked, underpowered vessel that was always on the verge of flying apart at the seams. In every measurable way, my Enterprise is a superior ship.  And yet... there are times I miss that cramped little Bridge very much.
There's one at the fleet museum. This is your Enterprise?

This is not an order, Geordi, it is a request... one which you are free to decline.  One of the most important things in a man's life is the need to feel useful. Mister Scott is a Starfleet officer... I would like him to feel useful again.
Understood.  Set a course.
Very well.
We read you, go ahead Commander.
What do you think of the Enterprise-D?
Why didn't we detect it before now?
You said you found a communications array?
... Beverly, we'll be arriving at Starbase One-Three-Three in a few hours...
And I doubt warp bubbles could alter computer records, or erase memories.  Keep at it, Ensign, Mister La Forge. It's the only working theory we have for now.
And this bubble never expanded beyond Engineering?
Are you suggesting this bubble could have made Doctor Quaice disappear?
As O'Brien didn't remember Doctor Quaice... ?
Beverly, you're saying this ship has lost nearly eight hundred of its personnel... ?
By all means check the trace log. But even if the results are negative, contact Starbase Command. We should leave nothing to chance.
Check shield and hull integrity for any sign of intruders...
Computer, search passenger requests. Doctor Dalen Quaice.
Could your friend have returned to the starbase without telling you? An emergency of some sort?
Did they come aboard with Doctor Quaice?
Did you find anything that might suggest why you're apparently the only one among us unaffected by this... phenomenon?
Doctor Quaice had been stationed at the starbase for some time?
Doctor, I believe I have been more than fair. I have done everything I can to substantiate your... your perceptions --
Doctor, may I see you in my Ready Room?
Doctor, one moment please.  I'm sure you are aware of procedures involving passengers.
Go ahead, Ensign.
Has something else happened?
Have security confine all nonessential personnel to their quarters. Computer, Red Alert.
How?
I cannot find any evidence...
I have no choice but to believe you. The safety of my crew is at stake. But I want to be sure...
I never received it.
I thought he was stationed there for six years.
I was not informed either.
I'll be in Engineering.
I've read your reports.
Is she alive?
Is there any possible connection to Mister Crusher's experiment... could this warp bubble be... floating around the ship perhaps...
It might be prudent to find out if he'd acquired any enemies there.
It wouldn't do any harm.
Mister Riker, set a course to return to Starbase One-Three-Three immediately.
Mister Worf?
None of the scans reveal any anomalies... there is no sign of an intruder... Wesley's experiment clearly did not have the scope to affect an entire starship...
Number One, any progress?
One thousand fourteen, including your guest, Doctor Quaice.
Perhaps you should confine yourself to Sickbay until we arrive...
Slow to ten meters per second.
Thank you, Mister Data.
Then give me a Level One diagnostic of all onboard sensors, and run a manual sweep for any anomalous airborne or electromagnetic readings. I want some answers.
Then how could it have trapped Doctor Quaice or the others?
Then it appears, for reasons unknown, someone has gone to great pains to erase all traces of this man.
Then it must have been intercepted before it reached me.
Until I disappear.
Very good, Number One. Mister Data?
Very well. Computer, continuous scan: Captain Jean-Luc Picard vital signs. Audible readout. Begin now.
Vividly. But if I have forgotten my closest friends and comrades, as you say, I deserved every word.
Was Doctor Quaice in Engineering during your experiment?
We've never needed a crew before.
Whom did you say?
You have my word... as soon as we return to the starbase, I'll make every effort to find him.
Your word has always been good enough for me.
A Romulan device.
Ambassador K'Ehleyr... This is an unexpected pleasure.
Ambassador K'ehleyr will be preparing me for my role in the rite of succession. But I have no doubt that I will be calling upon you for assistance as well, Lieutenant.
As Chief Security Officer, you will accompany me to the next transition proceeding.
Belay that order, Mister Data.
Both your claims have been properly made and recorded. We are ready for the final phase of the ja'chuq. There will be a recess while I review your petitions.
But does that suggest a Romulan connection?
But you've just said there are only two challengers arriving. What is the point?
Can the old form still be used?
Contact Gowron's ship, tell him to meet us aboard K'mpec's vessel. Ambassador, I'll meet you in Transporter Room Six in an hour. We'll begin the ceremony a little late.  Mister Worf.
Do you believe there is a threat to the Federation in this... struggle?
Do you wish to resign, Lieutenant?
Granted.
Granted.
He has a legal claim, Worf. Your personal feelings toward him...
He was murdered... poisoned.
How could Romulans have planted a bomb aboard a Klingon attack cruiser?
How may we be of assistance, Ambassador?
I choose to respect the ancient ritual. Each of you must prove your worthiness to lead the High Council.
I heard you were ill.
I hope this is brief.
I know that you're as concerned as I am about the explosion aboard K'mpec's ship. I assume both of your investigations are continuing...
I understand your pain... we all felt very close to K'Ehleyr.  A reprimand will be on your record. Dismissed.
I want you to know I am aware of your... discomfort.
I will determine how we proceed. If you wish to withdraw from the ja'chuq... that is your option.
I will?
I would hope you would not throw away a promising career.
I'm sorry... but I cannot discuss it.
If the Enterprise medical facility...
In good time, Duras.
Indeed.  It would put the Federation in a very uncomfortable position.
Initiate launch sequence.
Interesting? Yes, I would say that, since he conspired to strip Worf of his good name and tried to have me killed...
Is there some way of stretching out the formalities once they arrive?

Isn't it time for the truth about your father's innocence to be told? After all, the reasons you accepted this dishonor were to protect the name of Duras, and hold the Empire together. Now that he's died in disgrace... where is the honor in further silence?
It is my prerogative to investigate anything relevant to the Rite of Succession. Lieutenant Worf is my chief of security. His presence is required.
K'mpec believed the assassin to be either Duras or Gowron.
K'mpec. You can't be serious. A Federation officer has no business...

Klingon tradition may blame the son for the father's sins. I cannot, Worf. Treason was his father's disgrace. Duras' crime was to put that blame on your father... I will not forget that. But you should not forget that you chose to accept the consequences of that lie.
Lieutenant, please be sure to send a complete record of our findings to both vessels... and to the High Council.  We are adjourned.
Lieutenant, please receive our guest.
Lieutenant, you are a fine officer... your service aboard this ship has been exemplary...  Until now.
May I ask your reason?
Mister Worf, we now have a conspiracy on our hands that could be a direct threat to the security of the Federation.
No.
On screen.
On screen.
On the contrary, I think it is very different. And I must respectfully decline.
Open a channel, Mister Data.
Open channel.
Perhaps Duras or Gowron wishes to improve that relationship.
Picard... out.
Prepare two class one probes.
Qab... jIH... nagil
Sit down.
That's very interesting... because our analysis turned up some startling results.  Will you join us?

The Enterprise crew currently includes representatives from thirteen planets, Mister Worf. They each have their individual beliefs and values and I respect them all. But every member of the crew has chosen to serve Starfleet. If anyone cannot perform his duties because of the demands of his society, he must resign.
The High Council seems to agree with you. They consider the matter to be closed.  I do not.
The Sonchi ceremony will take place in one hour aboard K'mpec's ship.
The issue now is whether or not he killed K'mpec.
There is no delay. It is the time I have chosen.
This is not a case of simple mediation... you are asking me to choose the next leader of the Klingon Empire.
Very well. I accept.
We have had prior dealings with Duras that showed him to be... untrustworthy.
We haven't completed our analysis of the bomb debris... and Doctor Crusher is still studying the remains of the two men killed in the explosion.  We need more time.
We will begin the ja'chuq.
We will proceed according to the traditions and precedents set down in Klingon law.
We will reconvene on the Enterprise within---
What do you want of me?
Where is he?
Where's Worf?
Worf, I know the next couple of days will be difficult for you...
Worf...
Yes. It will.
You are a member of this crew, Lieutenant... and I will not have you go into hiding whenever a Klingon ship uncloaks.
You had no right to involve me without my permission.
You said "modern Rite"... how was the ritual performed in the past?
mev yap!
... so Gowron has come aboard in order to test your claim.
Boreth is twelve days from here by shuttle. As of this moment, you are on leave.
Does this have something to do with the Klingons you... rescued from Carraya Four?
Gentlemen, please. Let us stick to the issue at--

Gowron wants to run a genetic analysis on a sample of the blood and on you. It should tell us if there is a... biological match.  If you agree to the test... I will make the Enterprise facilities available to... ensure that it is conducted impartially.
Gowron would only say that there were certain... security concerns which prompted him to make this request. As the nearest starship to Boreth, the task is ours.
Have you lost your... faith in Sto-Vo-Kor?
He had no explanation at all?
He has brought a knife with him... a knife that was supposed to be stained with the blood of Kahless.
I assume you're referring to Kahless.
I hope you find what you're looking for, Mister Worf.  Because the next time you set foot on this ship I expect you to carry out your duties like a Starfleet officer.
I would be happy to arrange a tour of the entire ship for you, once you've settled in. Perhaps Commander Riker could begin by showing you your quarters.
If he's really an imposter you shouldn't have anything to worry about.
If you wanted to run tests on Kahless, you should've sent a Klingon vessel for him.

Inexcusable.  But understandable. You are the only Klingon in Starfleet... and one of the few raised by human parents. Perhaps the problem is that you have only studied the beliefs of your people... only looked at them from the outside.
Is that what you were doing here? Trying to recapture those feelings?

It may be that what you seek cannot be found on the Enterprise. You may need to immerse yourself in Klingon beliefs before you can discover whether they hold any truths for you.  Is there anything you could do... any place you could go... to explore your faith more fully?
It would seem that at least Gowron believes it. He personally contacted the Federation Council and asked that a starship be sent to bring Kahless back to the Home World.

Mister Worf, your personal affairs are strictly your concern unless they interfere with the operation of this ship. You've crossed that line. Now as your Captain, I want to know exactly what's going on.
Mister Worf?
No. All communication with Boreth has been cut-off since yesterday.
Of course.
Oh?
On your feet, Lieutenant.
Perhaps this Kahless is a... stalking horse for someone else... someone who intends to seize control from Gowron.
Set course for Boreth, Number One. Warp six.
Thank you.
Try.

We have no reason to rule out anything. We haven't been ordered to discover the origins of our guest, or tell anyone what they should believe... we are simply to transport Kahless to the Home World... and while he's with us, he will be treated as an honored guest.
We haven't done any analyses.
Welcome aboard the Enterprise. I'm Captain Jean-Luc Picard.
Welcome aboard, Gowron.
Well, the... person in question is in his quarters at the moment.
Where's Worf now?
Worf, what are his plans when he returns to the Home World?
You have the Bridge, Number One.
You might have tried using the Holodeck instead of setting your quarters on fire.
Are you certain it's artificially constructed?
But that's not possible. No ship of that time period could have come this far.
But you could revive them.
Can they hear us?
Can you identify?

Colonel Stephen Richey was the commanding officer of the explorer ship Charybdis which had a terrestrial launch date of 7-23-2067. It was the first manned attempt to travel beyond the confines of the Euclidian solar system. Its telemetry system failed and it was never heard from again...  Why is this of interest, Number One?
Come.
Energize.
Fermat's last theorem. Familiar with it?
Form an away team, minimal complement.
Get on it.
How long would they live under those conditions?
I find the process relaxing.
I understand the risk, but I will not warp off and leave them.  Make your preparations.
Is there an intelligence causing the interference?

It's intriguing. When Fermat died they found scrawled in the margin of his notes that he had found a "remarkable proof."  Unfortunately he never lived to write it down. And for the last eight hundred years people have been trying to rediscover it.
Let's see if we can find the architects.
Lock onto the landing party. Have the Transporter Room prepare to beam them up.
Make it so, Number One.
Make it so.

Number One... If we don't take some action, make some attempt -- however dangerous it may be -- to rescue you, you may very well be lost to the confines of that conundrum for all eternity. That is certain death for you all... and that...  ... that is unacceptable! We have set phaser focus with energy ratios sufficient to penetrate the structure --
Status report?
Suggestions?
Suppose we phaser a slice in the field which surrounds the structure?
That symbol... Do you recognize it?
The question is, how did it get here?
Then find another.
There's something here.
We can't transport.
What is going on down there?
What sort of markings?
What's your situation?
Where's that interference originating?
Why haven't you left the building, Number One?
Yet it does seem to be down there. Is there a connection between the structure and the ship?
A man needs to be careful about that sort of thing.
Absolutely not.
Clarify.
Complete waste of time...
Consider it captain's privilege.
Did you read that book I gave you?
E.t.a. thirteen-thirty hours.
Engage.
Ensign...Wesley. That's not true. I have great regard for you, for example. You're a fine young man.
Get on with it, Doctor. I've got work to do.
Good. I have some business of my own there. I shall accompany. you.
Good. Set the course for Epsilon Sector.  Warp five, Ensign.
Hardly.
I beg your pardon.
I didn't want you involved in this.
I do not say what I do not mean.

I had this one Nausicaan down on the floor in a particularly devious joint-lock when before I knew what was happening, one of his cohorts drew his weapon and impaled me through the back. Strange sensation, actually. Not much pain. Shock, certainly, at the sight of serrated metal coming out of one's chest, and then a certain giddy warmth. As I recall, I actually laughed aloud. It pierced my heart, of course, and if we hadn't been so near a medical facility I would surely have died.
I never said that.
I shouldn't be taking this trip at all. I belong back on the Enterprise.
I simply have... other priorities.
I understand you're heading for Starbase five one five.
I won't have you telling me what course to set!
I'm afraid not, Number One.

I'm pleased to report that Ensign Crusher's Starfleet exam results will enable him to continue with his studies on board the Enterprise. Furthermore, any rumors of my brush with death are greatly exaggerated. Is that clear?
I'm sorry. I don't mean to take it out on you.  I just hate going through another damned cardiac replacement.
I'm very well aware of that. You have the bridge. Carry on.
I've been looking forward to seeing the Epsilon Pulsar Cluster for myself.
If you're here... the entire crew must know...
Is it? How so?
It takes more than just that. Open your mind to the past... to history, art, philosophy. And then...  ... this will mean something.
It's certainly not my idea!

Just consider James' wisdom: "Philosophy... is not a technical matter... it is our sense of what life honestly means... our individual way of feeling the total push and pressure of the cosmos."  That's what I want for you.
Just pilot the shuttle, Ensign.
Let's just say I have personal reasons and leave it at that, shall we?
More like a late twenty-second century interplanetary journey.
My career always came first. I never had time.
No.  That's why I'm going in to get this thing replaced.
Not to worry. Ensign Crusher and I will rendezvous with you on your return from the Epsilon Pulsar Cluster.
Now you do.
Oh come on. This is a routine procedure. Quite commonplace.
Oh, please. I feel fine.
Prepare the shuttle for immediate departure.
Really? I've always had to work at it.
Several of us were on leave at Far Space Starbase Earhart... something of a galactic outpost in those days--
So did I.
Thank you.
Thank you.
That woman. She would.
That's not the point. Not only am I in splendid health, but it would be inappropriate for you to perform the procedure.
That's reassuring.

That's right. My mates and I were at the Bonestell Recreation Facility, which was nothing more than a crossroads at the time. A trio of Nausicaans came in. They were spoiling for a confrontation with some fresh-faced young Starfleet officers like ourselves. Everyone in our group had the good sense to back away and give these Nausicaans wide berth. Everyone but me, that is. I stood toe-to-toe with the nastiest of the three and let him know what I thought of him, his partners, and his planet. I probably even made some passing reference to his questionable parentage.
The cardiac replacement procedure. It has a very low mortality rate. Two point four percent.
The fact is, I'm not interested in having my innards become the subject of Starfleet gossip.
The important things never will be. Anyone can be trained to deal with technology, and the mechanics of piloting a starship.

Then nothing. I was no hero. I was an undisciplined, opinionated, loud-mouthed young man who was far out of his league. It was a great and painful lesson, but I learned it well. I only hope you won't need to learn it as I did...
There have been certain costs involved.
There is no greater challenge than the study of philosophy.
This has nothing to do with ship's business.  Suffice it to say that this is strictly a matter of ...vanity.
This ship has a mission to carry out.
Van Doren's technique has been perfected to two point four percent.
Well... I was a young Starfleet officer. Just a few years older than you are now. Green as hell. Top of my Academy Class, and oh, so proud. Too proud, as it turned out.
What else would it be?  My own heart was injured and a replacement was necessary. That would have been it except that the replacement is flawed and must now be put right.
What in the hell are you doing here?
What is it, Number One?
What is it?
What?
Why do I get the feeling you're acting like some kind of escort?
Wishing for a thing does not make it so.
You don't want to be late for your exams, Ensign.
You should read more history, Ensign.
Actually, I came to see you.
Ambassador Sarek, Perrin... on behalf of my entire crew, welcome.
Ambassador, please be assured that everything will be ready by the time the conference begins.
And when the Legarans beam aboard...
Are you suggesting it is somehow contagious?
At your convenience, Commander.
Believe me, nothing would give me greater pleasure. But there's nothing I can do.
Beverly...
But at what cost, Number One?
But you did need his help at the concert.
By all means.
Come.
Come.
Doctor Crusher will be monitoring our responses.
Don't you tell me...
Has the ambassador been delayed?
He cried. I saw that. I didn't believe it. A Vulcan moved to tears by music... ?
He is very ill, Perrin.
He knows. More than that, he has been consciously holding Sarek's mind together on this mission as well as he could...
He will never lose that respect.
He... loves you... very much.
High praise from a Vulcan.
How is the ambassador?
I am aware of the risks, Sarek. But I believe it is the only... logical solution.
I believe I got the best part of that bargain, Ambassador.
I believe you are affected, sir... far more than you realize.
I can't imagine anything that would be more offensive to a Vulcan. Their emotional detachment is the very core of their being.  But why would it affect others aboard the ship?
I can't stop them...
I cannot explain that. Hundreds of others on board have not been affected either. I have not. The effects appear to be random. Proximity apparently has no bearing on the phenomenon.
I didn't expect you would, Beverly.
I find that hard to believe.
I have come to extend my personal invitation to you... and your husband, if he is available, to attend a Mozart recital this evening.
I have twelve hours.
I hope I have not embarrassed you, Ambassador.
I hope I'm not intruding.
I hope I'm that frail when I'm two hundred and two. His aides did seem a little overprotective, didn't they?
I hope you are wrong, Ambassador.

There are many things about her species that cannot be easily explained. Even she cannot explain how or why she senses that history has been altered. And yet it is very possible she is correct. A ship from the past has traveled through time. Who among us could know what effect that event has had on the present. Indeed, we will never know for certain if Guinan is correct. But I, for one, have decided the consequences of that possibility are too grave to ignore.
There's no logic in it at all.  Tasha, whether they succeed or not, the Enterprise-C will be destroyed...
They shouldn't be so confident... after the pasting we gave them at Archer Four.
Very well. Prepare a class-one sensor probe. We'll leave it behind to monitor the final closure. Mister Crusher, lay in a course for Archer Four.
We can't do that. If we send this ship back with new technology... we would be altering the past...

We could, of course, outrun the Klingons, but we must protect the Enterprise-C until she can enter the temporal rift.  We may not survive... but we must succeed... Let's make sure they don't forget the name Enterprise.
We will maintain position to provide cover.  Make it so.
We'll handle this one step at a time. Stabilize power systems and attend to their casualties. Avoid discussions of where and when they are.
We're talking about restoring the past.
What else?
What is the last thing you remember?
What things? What people?
What's the matter with it?
Who is to say this history is any less proper than the other?
Yes, Lieutenant.
You are aboard the Enterprise, Captain... one-seven-oh-one-D.
You have come twenty-two years into the future.
You must have some idea how things have changed...
You're needed here.
